subject: Classpath dunce trying to organize Junit and project files

messageBody:
Hello. I have been using junit successfully for several weeks, but
have only been able to run tests which I locate directly below junit
itself. I'm tired of relocating packages to the junit hierarchy to
test them, and I'm sure I should be able to run tests on any package
anywhere if I have my system path and classpath set up correctly.
Just haven't gotten it right yet...

I have read all the junit.org documentation and articles about
organizing test cases into suites, etc., but have not seen anything
that specifically explains how to run TestRunner against packages
located elsewhere on the drive.

Can someone please tell me what I'm doing wrong in terms of setup:

I have various Java projects stored as d:\projects\projname and am
attempting J2EE format, so for any particular project named ABC the
source is located at
d:\projects\projABC\source\java\com\companyname\ABC\
with subfolders as needed below that.

My corresponding junit tests are in a parallel structure at
d:\projects\projABC\tests\java\com\companyname\ABC\

The class files for the source are located at
d:\abc_webapp\web-inf\classes\com\companyname\ABC\

The class files for my junit test files are located in the same place
as the test files themselves.

In each test class, the package statement says
package com.companyname.abc;

and the import statements are whatever is needed from java/javax plus
whatever is needed from the project source plus
import junit.framework.*;

I develop on an NT machine. I've got classpath pointing to
d:\projects\projABC\source\java (although this seems unnecessary)
and
d:\projects\projABC\tests\java
and
d:\abc_webapp\web-inf\classes
and
d:\junit3_7 (although this seems unnecessary)
and
d:\junit3_7\junit.jar

I've got path pointing to
d:\projects\projABC\tests\java
and
d:\junit3_7
and
d:\junit3_7\junit.jar (although this seems unnecessary)

In a command prompt window, I cannot run the junit TestRunner from
anyplace other than down in the junit3_7 folder, so I drop down
there. Then I can run all of the Junit TestRunner variations, but
when I try to reference a test class located elsewhere on the hard
drive using com.companyname.abc.SomeTest I get a "class not found"
error.

Hopefully I'm just missing the boat on something simple. Thanks for
your help.

- DJ

P.S. - Also, any further advice about how to better organize test
files in relation to project files would be welcome. Putting them in
a structure parallel to the source code made sense to me, but might
not be the best.
